entry.title: Who defines a PC
entry.summary: The PC was defined by IBM and Microsoft. Who defines it today?

div.p: Tablets, eReaders, Smartbooks: You Name the Device and It’s News at Computex writes Katie Morgan of Advanced Risc Machines (ARM). You may not know about it, but just as Intel rules the desktop, the British chip design company's ARM Architecture rules the pockets.

According to Wikipedia, 90%+ of all processors in mobile phones and embedded devices are equipped with this architecture. This means that there's.a fair chance that both your phone, your wireless router and your fridge are all ARM systems.

The mobiles & the tablets are given prominent positions in the news feeds, and as I write this there one such item in top of Google News' Sci/Tech section. It is about Apple's iPhone, which, by the way, like the Android systems, are ARM.

Intel has tried to establish itself in this area, have not been able to do so through can getting an increased market share by winning customers from ARM. The tablets is a new segment, and the race to start exploit the unchartered land. The chip Intel try to market here is the Atom processor which, of course, is x86.

Google's Android & Chromium are both Linux platforms (hence Helsinki & Stanford Universities), whereas iPhone OS is a redecorated Berkeley Unix with a Mach kernel. Yes, it is a Mach kernel, as in the speed of sound. This makes these gadgets University of California & Carnegie Mellon University.
All of a sudden we see new and sometimes unexpected alliances. Two examples:

ul.li: Global leaders Intel Corporation and Nokia merge Moblin and Maemo to create MeeGo*, a Linux-based …
ARM, Freescale, IBM, Samsung, ST-Ericsson and Texas Instruments Form New Company to Speed the Rollout of Linux-Based Devices

div.p: I read and write mail, manage my calendars, surf and do a better part of my wordprocessing with my tablet. I also do some authoring on it, which requires programming and XML tools such as an XSLT processor.

Hence, I want a hand-held computer which enables me.to do much the same things I've done using my laptop. One could say that this is one of many the preliminary answers to the questions the industry is posing to the market.

The vendors have obviously radically different views on the future of computing. Recently Steve Jobs claimed that the PC as we know it is like an old truck and that the future belongs to the tablets. Steve Ballmer participated in the same conference and disputed these claims. He seemed to be convinced that the desktop PC will.continue to be the workstation for a foreseeable future.

The PC as we know it will continue to morph, he said. The real question is what are you going to push. In Microsoft’s case, the answer is more machines that run flavors of Windows. To a man with a hammer everything looks like a nail; we have a hammer, Mr. Ballmer joked.
